claim: Prioritization must be customer-centric: evaluate features primarily on how well they solve real user problems. Data from analytics and feedback should drive decisions, not executive opinions or internal politics.
rationale: Features built without understanding user pain points waste resources and miss market fit. Customer-centric prioritization ensures development effort addresses what users actually need, not what stakeholders assume they want.

claim: Use RICE scoring: (Reach × Impact × Confidence) ÷ Effort. This quantifies the value-to-effort ratio, ensuring resources flow to features with highest return per unit of investment.
rationale: RICE forces explicit estimation of who's affected (Reach), how much (Impact), certainty level (Confidence), and cost (Effort). The formula surfaces high-value, low-effort opportunities that intuition often misses.

claim: Apply Value vs. Effort Matrix to visualize trade-offs: High Value/Low Effort = Quick Wins (do first), High Value/High Effort = Major Projects (plan carefully), Low Value/Low Effort = Fill-ins (spare capacity), Low Value/High Effort = Time Sinks (avoid).
rationale: Visual mapping enables rapid collaborative assessment and reveals the strategic implications of each feature at a glance. Quick Wins deliver immediate returns; Time Sinks drain resources for minimal benefit.

claim: Use MoSCoW for scope definition: Must-have (product won't work without it), Should-have (important but not critical), Could-have (nice if time permits), Won't-have (explicitly excluded). Too many Must-haves signals poor prioritization.
rationale: MoSCoW creates clear boundaries that prevent scope creep and manage stakeholder expectations. Explicit Won't-haves reduce endless debates about deferred features.

claim: Build custom Weighted Scoring models when off-the-shelf frameworks don't fit. Define 5-10 criteria relevant to your context, assign percentage weights summing to 100%, score each feature, calculate weighted totals.
rationale: Generic frameworks can't capture unique strategic priorities. Custom weighting forces explicit articulation of what matters most—retention vs. acquisition, compliance vs. speed—making trade-offs transparent and defensible.

claim: Every prioritized feature needs feature-specific KPIs defined before development begins. Establish baselines, implement tracking, monitor post-launch, and validate whether the feature delivered its promised value.
rationale: Without measurable success criteria, you can't know if prioritization decisions were correct. Post-launch validation closes the feedback loop, improving future prioritization accuracy.

claim: A/B test high-uncertainty features before full commitment. Run experiments on user subsets, measure against predefined KPIs, and use statistical significance to validate or invalidate prioritization assumptions.
rationale: A/B testing provides empirical evidence that confirms or refutes impact estimates. Features with proven positive impact get full rollout; features that fail tests get deprioritized before wasting major resources.

claim: Allocate 15-20% of sprint capacity explicitly for technical debt and maintenance. Treat infrastructure health as high-value work that prevents long-term velocity degradation.
rationale: Technical debt compounds—codebases become harder to work with, bugs increase, developers burn out. Explicit allocation prevents the 'future me will fix it' trap that eventually cripples innovation ability.

claim: The HiPPO Effect: allowing the Highest Paid Person's Opinion to drive prioritization without data leads to misaligned roadmaps, wasted resources, and products that fail to meet market demands.
rationale: Senior stakeholders have blind spots and pet projects. Without data-driven frameworks, backlogs reflect organizational politics rather than customer value, undermining product-market fit.

claim: Over-committing and under-delivering: agreeing to too many features or unrealistic timelines leads to missed deadlines, incomplete work, burned-out teams, and lost stakeholder trust.
rationale: The desire to please stakeholders or inability to say 'no' creates a cycle of disappointment. Teams lose credibility, morale drops, and the organization learns it can't rely on product commitments.

claim: Lack of stakeholder alignment: when sales, marketing, engineering, and leadership aren't aligned on priorities, they push competing agendas, undermine the roadmap, and create internal friction that slows everything.
rationale: Prioritization is a team sport. Without collaborative input and transparent rationale, departments optimize locally rather than for the product, and feel excluded from decisions that affect their work.

claim: Neglecting technical debt for features creates compounding slowdown. Codebases become harder to work with, bugs increase, developers burn out, and feature delivery actually slows over time.
rationale: Technical debt is invisible to stakeholders but real to engineers. Continuous deferral creates a 'debt spiral' where maintenance consumes increasing capacity, eventually crippling innovation ability.

claim: Strategic Alignment as weighted criterion: explicitly include 'Strategic Alignment' at 20-30% weight in scoring models. Features that don't contribute to strategic objectives get deprioritized regardless of individual appeal.
rationale: Without strategic filtering, backlogs become collections of individually appealing but strategically disconnected features. Explicit weighting ensures every feature traces to business goals.

claim: Risk as prioritization criterion: integrate Technical Risk, Market Risk, and Regulatory Risk into scoring models. High-risk features need de-risking spikes or MVTs before full development commitment.
rationale: Ignoring risk leads to costly failures and delays. Explicit risk assessment surfaces features needing validation, allows proactive mitigation, and prevents betting big on uncertain assumptions.

claim: Continuous discovery loops: embed ongoing user research, analytics monitoring, and feedback channels into daily workflow. Make prioritization a continuous stream of learning, not periodic batch exercises.
rationale: Markets and users change constantly. Periodic prioritization creates lag between insights and action. Continuous discovery ensures the backlog always reflects current understanding of user needs.

claim: Netflix's continuous experimentation: every feature is a hypothesis tested via large-scale A/B tests on millions of users. Only features with proven positive impact on engagement/retention get full rollout.
rationale: Netflix doesn't rely on executive intuition—they empirically validate every prioritization assumption. Features that don't move metrics get discarded or iterated, ensuring only proven value ships.

claim: Spotify's Discover Weekly prioritization: identified 'listening fatigue' as core user problem, hypothesized personalized playlists would increase engagement, iteratively developed ML-powered discovery features based on performance data.
rationale: Spotify prioritized solving a deep user problem (music discovery) rather than surface-level feature requests. Data-driven refinement of personalization algorithms created a powerful retention moat.

claim: Airbnb's trust feature prioritization: after early trust issues, prioritized Host Guarantee, Verified ID, and Review Systems as Must-haves despite high effort, because trust was critical for marketplace viability.
rationale: Airbnb recognized that trust features were non-negotiable for a peer-to-peer marketplace, even though they were expensive to build. Strategic necessity overrode short-term ROI calculations.

claim: If too many items are labeled 'Must-have' in MoSCoW, the categories need re-evaluation. True Must-haves are features without which the product won't work—typically a small subset of the backlog.
rationale: Overloaded Must-have categories indicate stakeholder pressure overriding honest assessment, or fear of making hard trade-offs. This defeats the purpose of prioritization.

claim: Low Confidence scores in RICE indicate you're prioritizing based on assumptions, not evidence. Features with <50% Confidence should trigger further investigation or validation before major investment.
rationale: The Confidence component explicitly acknowledges uncertainty. Consistently low confidence across high-priority features signals the backlog is built on unvalidated assumptions requiring de-risking.
